files.patch:
@@ -1091,4 +1091,6 @@ - * Initiates handshaking on this SSLEngine. Common reasons include a need - * to initiate a new session, to use new encryption keys or to change - * cipher suites. To force complete reauthentication, the current session - * could be invalidated before starting this handshake. + * Begins handshaking on this {@code SSLEngine}. + *

+ * Common reasons include a need to initiate a new protected session, + * create new encryption keys, or to change cipher suites. To force + * complete reauthentication, the current session should be invalidated + * before starting this handshake. @@ -1097,4 +1099,3 @@ - * dependent. For example, in TLSv1.3 and later versions calling this - * method after the connection has been established will force producing - * a KeyUpdate message. For prior TLS versions it will force a - * renegotiation (re-handshake). + * dependent. For example, in TLSv1.3 calling this method after the + * connection has been established will force a key update. For prior TLS + * versions it will force a renegotiation (re-handshake).

@@ -505,4 +505,6 @@ - * Initiates handshaking on this connection. Common reasons include a need - * to initiate a new session, to use new encryption keys or to change - * cipher suites. To force complete reauthentication, the current session - * could be invalidated before starting this handshake. + * Starts handshaking on this {@code SSLSocket}. + *

+ * Common reasons include a need to initiate a new protected session, + * create new encryption keys, or to change cipher suites. To force + * complete reauthentication, the current session should be invalidated + * before starting this handshake. @@ -511,4 +513,3 @@ - * dependent. For example, in TLSv1.3 and later versions calling this - * method after the connection has been established will force producing - * a KeyUpdate message. For prior TLS versions it will force a - * renegotiation (re-handshake). + * dependent. For example, in TLSv1.3 calling this method after the + * connection has been established will force a key update. For prior TLS + * versions it will force a renegotiation (re-handshake).
